title: Practice Challenge
description:
Create a simple API for a todo list using Hono patterns:

1. Create a GET route `/api/todos` that returns an array of todo objects
   - Each todo should have: id, task, completed
   - Use c.json() to return the data

2. Create a POST route `/api/todos` that:
   - Simulates creating a new todo
   - Returns status 201 and the new todo using c.json(data, 201)

3. Create a GET route `/api/todos/completed` that:
   - Returns only completed todos

Use the HonoApp class from the example. Simulate requests to test your routes.
instructions:
Create a simple API for a todo list using Hono patterns:

1. Create a GET route `/api/todos` that returns an array of todo objects
   - Each todo should have: id, task, completed
   - Use c.json() to return the data

2. Create a POST route `/api/todos` that:
   - Simulates creating a new todo
   - Returns status 201 and the new todo using c.json(data, 201)

3. Create a GET route `/api/todos/completed` that:
   - Returns only completed todos

Use the HonoApp class from the example. Simulate requests to test your routes.

testCases.description: Should return all todos using c.json()

hints.text: In Hono, use (c) => { return c.json(data); } pattern. For status codes, pass as second argument: c.json(data, 201)

commonMistakes.mistake: Forgetting to return the response in Hono
commonMistakes.consequence: The route handler returns undefined and no response is sent.
commonMistakes.correction: Always return c.json(), c.text(), etc. Example: return c.json({ data });

commonMistakes.mistake: Using Express (req, res) pattern instead of Hono (c) pattern
commonMistakes.consequence: Code will not work correctly with Hono's context object.
commonMistakes.correction: Use (c) => { return c.json(data); } instead of (req, res) => { res.json(data); }

commonMistakes.mistake: Putting status code in wrong place
commonMistakes.consequence: Status code may not be set correctly.
commonMistakes.correction: In Hono, status is the second argument: c.json(data, 201)
